title: Are high school clubs in Japan actually unsupervised like in anime? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Unsupervised” is overstating the issue. Every club has a sponsoring teacher who is responsible for signing off on budgets, activities and the like. But, as with many things in Japanese schools, the idea behind clubs is to let children learn to be autonomous, to make decisions, do paperwork, manage the money and gain leadership skills. So team/club captains/presidents are allowed to make decisions that, in an American school would be left to teachers. Of course, there’s the weight of precedent that constrains many of the decisions, so it’s not as open to interpretation as anime makes it seems. Anime also skips over the administrative aspects of clubs. For most schools (this was true in my high school and university, as well) a club has to fill out a metric ton of paperwork to get started. It needs rules of order, a clear hierarchy. A minimum of 5 people is the absolute smallest I ever saw a club - president, vice-president, treasurer and two non-officer members. But. There are also not-official clubs. I ran one in grad school. We met monthly at a student center, did projects, chatted, had pizza. I’m still good friends with a couple of the folks I met in that club, too. (Just realized that that was 25 years ago, holy shit.) We never did any of the paperwork, never got permission to use school grounds, nothing, but the club lasted almost two years and we had a blast! So, realistically, I bet there are plenty of “circles” in Japanese schools that form like that, even if they aren’t official clubs. And they wouldn’t have any of the paperwork, since they weren’t official.

It may be dependent on the school but from what I’ve seen and experienced there is always at least one teacher present, be it the main teacher or assistant teacher. The students do most of the administrative and paper work however. I never had clubs like this in New Zealand so it’s all new to me. Teachers involve themselves just as much in club activities as the students do, giving up weekends and staying late. For me this is mind boggling, just as mind boggling for them that we don’t have clubs!One of my friends is the assistant “coach” for the baseball team, though she’s never been remotely interested in baseball before. Newer teachers don’t get to choose which club they are assigned to, and may only be involved with that club for a year or two, so it makes sense that the students in those clubs take more control over the running of them. Maybe there are cases where the teacher leaves the students to themselves because they believe the students are capable of doing it by themselves but I’ve never seen it. I am in charge of the English conversation club at my school and generally if I’m not there for any reason the club is cancelled. It seems at my school a teacher always has to be present. Anime exaggerates a lot of situations, naturally, school life not being an exception. I cannot compare Japanese clubs with American clubs, but teachers always seem to be present at clubs while students do the paper work.

This may seem odd to Americans, but the schools are “owned” by the students. They have classes, and they “own” the classroom. The teachers are invited in to teach, they do not have a permanent desk or assignment there. The same is mostly true for clubs. They are owned by the students, run by students, and only nominally supervised by assigned teachers. Some have close supervision, like bands; others have coaches, like archery or baseball. Some are more autonomous, like History Club or Anime Club. They will be given a place to meet, and a time, and typically assigned a teacher who is their nominal supervisor. Sometimes the clubs meet every day, and others its every week. The student council manages budget for clubs as well as space assignment, in many schools. Student run and managed, for the most part. The teacher facilitates and keeps them safe, but for some clubs its more like a coach or conductor.

Clubs in anime are really not all that different from clubs in the USA, at least when I was in high school. In the schools I attended, clubs needed a teacher as a supervisor but the students usually ran it, aside from the SJW club which was run by the activist teacher and student leaders were just his “yes men.” For most clubs I was in, the teachers rarely or never showed up to meetings and really didn’t care much about them, so they’d be similar to what is usually portrayed in anime relating to non-athletic clubs. When my brother was in high school, his role-playing game club was so unsupervised he actually ran a small gambling club inside of it to make money for lunch. I actually made up the game they used but for use within a role-playing game, but they used it in the real world for real money. In my school I don’t think we even had budgets, especially since I ran two clubs and never was told about anything related to money. Clubs usually did their own fund raisers if they wanted funds. A big difference with the clubs I was in an anime clubs was that we met during lunch rather than after school, with the exception of the semester I was in the Bowling Club.

Hah! You wish! One misconception about anime is that, the people who make the anime try to make it as entertaining as possible. Do get what I'm trying to imply here. If clubs were unsupervised like in the amines, I would not have been busted for skipping Table tennis for 1 week straight. Ok… actually, some clubs are unsupervised by teachers in my school, but most have a teacher assigned to every club. Hope this answer helps! (For what I have absolutely no idea)
